qas.question: How are things in statistical mechanics?
What are superior to classical thermodynamics?
In order to explain glass breaking, Fundamental laws of physics can be paired with what?
Is statistical mechanics asymmetric or symmetric in regards to time-reversal?

What type of mechanics help to simplify things?
What is superior to statistical mechanics?
What thermodynamic behavior can not be explained by the fundemental laws of physics?
What is an abso;ute law in statistical mechanics?

context: But in <b5_0>statistical mechanics<b5_0/> things get more <a0_0>complicated<a0_0/>. On one hand, <a1_0>statistical mechanics<a1_0/> is far superior to <b6_0>classical thermodynamics<b6_0/>, in that thermodynamic behavior, such as <b7_0>glass breaking<b7_0/>, can be explained by the fundamental laws of physics paired with <a2_0>a statistical postulate<a2_0/>. But statistical mechanics, unlike classical thermodynamics, is time-reversal <a3_0>symmetric<a3_0/>. The second law of thermodynamics, as it arises in statistical mechanics, merely states that it is overwhelmingly likely that <b8_0>net entropy will increase<b8_0/>, but it is <a4_0>not an absolute law<a4_0/>.
